abstract.p: Prof Walter A McDougall letter says Stephen E Ambrose's June 19 Op-Ed article did not go far enough in describing similarities in styles of Pres Clinton and former president Dwight D Eisenhower (S)

block.p: In ''How Clinton Is Like Ike'' (Op-Ed, June 19), Stephen E. Ambrose rightly suggests that Dwight D. Eisenhower, like Bill Clinton, ''moved to the center on the issues of the day, at the expense of all-out support from his core constituency, in his case the Republican right.'' But Mr. Ambrose could have gone further.

In ''How Clinton Is Like Ike'' (Op-Ed, June 19), Stephen E. Ambrose rightly suggests that Dwight D. Eisenhower, like Bill Clinton, ''moved to the center on the issues of the day, at the expense of all-out support from his core constituency, in his case the Republican right.'' But Mr. Ambrose could have gone further.

As a popular two-term president from the opposing party who refused to roll back the New Deal, Ike served to consolidate the Roosevelt revolution. Mr. Clinton has likewise served to consolidate the Reagan revolution by balancing the budget, reforming welfare and unleashing the private sector. That explains why ''movement conservatives'' rose up in protest to Eisenhower, and why much of the American left considers Mr. Clinton a traitor.
WALTER A. MC DOUGALL Philadelphia, June 19, 2000
The writer is a professor of history at the University of Pennsylvania.
